newsitem.title: USA: Ex-soldier found guilty of Carolina race murders.
newsitem.headline: Ex-soldier found guilty of Carolina race murders.

text.p: A North Carolina jury on Thursday found a white former U.S. Army paratrooper guilty of murdering a black couple in 1995.

James Burmeister, 21, who has been linked to a white supremacist group, was unanimously found guilty of two counts of first-degree murder for the deaths of Jackie Burden and Michael James, who were shot at close range as they walked in a Fayetteville neighborhood on Dec. 7, 1995.
Fayetteville adjoins the U.S. Army's Fort Bragg, home to the 82nd Airborne, and Burmeister was drinking in a bar there with two fellow soldiers before the murders.
Burmeister was also found guilty of conspiracy to commit murder. Prosecutors were expected to seek the death penalty when the trial enters the penalty phase during the afternoon.
A life sentence would make Burmeister eligible for parole after 25 years behind bars.

Jurors deliberated for about 10 hours over three days. Shortly before reaching a decision, they asked to review statements by soldier Randy Meadows, who pleaded guilty to involvement in the crime and became the prosecution's key witness against Burmeister.
